title: Differential Expression Analysis
code: library(PRONE)

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: , directly working SummarizedExperiment data. information create SummarizedExperiment proteomics data set, please refer “Get Started” vignette. example TMT data set originates (Biadglegne et al. 2022).
code: data("tuberculosis_TMT_se") se <- tuberculosis_TMT_se

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: order compare performance different normalization methods ability detect differentially expressed proteins, performed normalization batch effect correction technqiues . details normalize data evaluate normalization approaches quantitatively qualitatively using PRONE, please refer “Normalization” vignette.
code: se_norm <- normalize_se(se, c("IRS_on_RobNorm", "IRS_on_Median",                                "IRS_on_LoessF", "IRS_on_Quantile"),                          combination_pattern = "_on_") #> IRS normalization performed on RobNorm-normalized data completed. #> IRS normalization performed on Median-normalized data completed. #> LoessF normalization not yet performed. Single LoessF normalization performed now. #> LoessF completed. #> IRS normalization performed on LoessF-normalized data completed. #> Quantile normalization not yet performed. Single Quantile normalization performed now. #> Quantile completed. #> IRS normalization performed on Quantile-normalized data completed.

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: performed normalization evaluated different normalization methods via qualitative quantitative analysis, differential expression analysis can used analyze differences normalization methods assess impact normalization downstream analyses. However , need remove reference samples case TMT experiment. can easily done function remove_reference_samples().
code: se_norm <- remove_reference_samples(se_norm) #> 2 reference samples removed from the SummarizedExperiment object.

previous_headings: 4 Differential Expression Analysis > 4.1 Run DE Analysis
title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: First, need specify comparisons want perform DE analysis. , function specify_comparisons() developed helps build right comparison strings. However, can also just simply create vector comparisons ensure correct order handle vector DE analysis method. function specify_comparisons() becomes handy lot sample groups foremost samples multiple conditions (case dataset). instance, data set diabetic healthy samples (condition) measured day 3 (3d), day 7 (7d), day 17 (d14) operation (timepoints. DE analysis, want perform comparisons diabetic healthy samples time point also different time points fixed condition (e.g. diabetic). Instead writing comparisons manually, function helps build right comparison strings considering comparisons least one groups (timepoint condition) remains static. need column metadata named instance “Condition” combines two groups “”, values diabetic_3d, diabetic_7d, diabetic_14d, etc. function specify column name ”Condition” separator (sep = ””).
code: comparisons <- specify_comparisons(se_norm, condition = "Group",                                     sep = NULL, control = NULL)  comparisons <- c("PTB-HC", "TBL-HC", "TBL-PTB", "Rx-PTB")

previous_headings: 4 Differential Expression Analysis > 4.1 Run DE Analysis
title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: function run_DE() performs DE analysis selected SummarizedExperiment comparisons. novel feature PRONE compare DE results different normalization methods shown normalization impact downstream analyses. Therefore, DE analysis can performed multiple assays (normalization methods) using already known “ain” parameter. following, detailed explanation parameters given: condition SummarizedExperiment object, specified beginning, can used (condition = NULL) column meta data can specified. Three methods available DE analysis: limma (Ritchie et al. 2015), DEqMS (Zhu et al. 2020), ROTS (Suomi et al. 2017). logFC parameter specifies log2 fold change calculated. logFC_up logFC_down parameters specify log2 fold change thresholds - -regulated proteins. p_adj parameter specifies p-values adjusted. alpha parameter specifies significance level p-values. addition, following parameters specific DE analysis methods: covariate parameter can used include covariate DE analysis case limma performed. can column meta data. trend parameter specifies trend test performed case limma used. robust parameter specifies robust method used case limma used. B number bootstrapping K number top-ranked features reproducibility optimization. DEqMS_PSMs_column need specified. can column rowData(se) represents number quantified peptides PSMs. used DEqMS estimate prior variance proteins quantified different number PSMs. want apply logFC p-value threshold, need re-run DE analysis . apply_thresholds(), can simply change threshold values. instance, want apply logFC threshold consider proteins adjusted p-value 0.05 DE, just set logFC parameter FALSE. case, proteins classified - -regulated significant change change. However, still want see protein positive negative logFC, can set logFC parameter TRUE logFC_up logFC_down parameters 0.
code: de_res <- run_DE(se = se_norm,                       comparisons = comparisons,                      ain = NULL,                       condition = NULL,                       DE_method = "limma",                       logFC = TRUE,                       logFC_up = 1,                       logFC_down = -1,                       p_adj = TRUE,                       alpha = 0.05,                      covariate = NULL,                       trend = TRUE,                      robust = TRUE,                      B = 100,                      K = 500                  )  #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> DE Analysis will not be performed on raw data. #> log2: DE analysis completed. #> RobNorm: DE analysis completed. #> IRS_on_RobNorm: DE analysis completed. #> Median: DE analysis completed. #> IRS_on_Median: DE analysis completed. #> LoessF: DE analysis completed. #> IRS_on_LoessF: DE analysis completed. #> Quantile: DE analysis completed. #> IRS_on_Quantile: DE analysis completed. new_de_res <- apply_thresholds(de_res = de_res, logFC = FALSE, p_adj = TRUE,                                 alpha = 0.05) new_de_res <- apply_thresholds(de_res = de_res, logFC = TRUE,                                 logFC_up = 0, logFC_down = 0,                                 p_adj = TRUE, alpha = 0.05)

previous_headings: 4 Differential Expression Analysis > 4.2 Visualize DE Results
title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: get overview DE results different normalization methods, can visualize number significant DE proteins per normalization method barplot using plot_overview_DE_bar(). plot can generated different ways specifying “plot_type” parameter: single: plot single barplot comparison (default) facet_comp: facet barplot comparison stacked: stack number DE per comparison facet_regulation: stack number DE per comparison facet - -regulated Figure 4.1: Barplot showing number DE proteins per normalization method colored comparison facetted - -regulation. can also just visualize two specific comparisons: Figure 4.2: Barplot showing number DE proteins per normalization method faceted comparison.
code: plot_overview_DE_bar(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons,                       plot_type = "facet_regulation") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. plot_overview_DE_bar(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons[seq_len(2)],                       plot_type = "facet_comp") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized.

previous_headings: 4 Differential Expression Analysis > 4.2 Visualize DE Results > 4.2.1 Barplot
title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: can also get overview DE results form heatmap using plot_overview_DE_tile(). Figure 4.3: Heatmap showing number DE proteins per comparison per normalization method.
code: plot_overview_DE_tile(de_res) #> All comparisons of de_res will be visualized. #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized.

previous_headings: 4 Differential Expression Analysis > 4.2 Visualize DE Results > 4.2.1 Barplot
title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: Another option generate volcano plots comparison. function plot_volcano_DE() generates grid volcano plots normalization techniques (facet_norm = TRUE) comparison (facet_comparison = TRUE). list volcano plots returned. Figure 4.4: Volcano plots per normalization method single comparison.
code: plot_volcano_DE(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons[1],                  facet_norm = TRUE) #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. #> $`PTB-HC`

previous_headings: 4 Differential Expression Analysis > 4.2 Visualize DE Results > 4.2.1 Barplot
title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: Furthermore, can visualize DE results form heatmap. function plot_heatmap_DE() generates heatmap DE results specific comparison normalization method. Figure 4.5: Individual heatmap DE results specific comparison selection normalization methods. adjusted p-values added row annotation, condition sample shown column annotation. Figure 4.6: Individual heatmap DE results specific comparison selection normalization methods. adjusted p-values added row annotation, condition sample shown column annotation.
code: plot_heatmap_DE(se_norm, de_res, ain = c("RobNorm", "IRS_on_RobNorm"),                  comparison = "PTB-HC", condition = NULL, label_by = NULL,                  pvalue_column = "adj.P.Val") #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> <simpleError in stats::hclust(stats::dist(as.matrix(data))): NA/NaN/Inf in foreign function call (arg 10)> #> <simpleError in stats::hclust(stats::dist(as.matrix(data))): NA/NaN/Inf in foreign function call (arg 10)> #> $RobNorm #>  #> $IRS_on_RobNorm

previous_headings: 4 Differential Expression Analysis > 4.2 Visualize DE Results
title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: Moreover, can also intersect DE results different normalization methods see many DE proteins overlap. can either plot requested comparison individual upset plot (plot_type = “single”) stack number overlapping DE proteins per comparison (“stacked”). upset plot(s) returned, also table intersections provided plot_upset_DE()function. Figure 4.7: Upset plot showing overlapping DE proteins different normalization methods colored comparison. Additionally, Jaccard similarity index can calculated quantify similarity DE results different normalization methods. individual heatmap can generated comparison (“plot_type = single”), single heatmap facetted comparison (“facet_comp”) single heatmap taking comparisons account (“”) can generated. Figure 4.8: Heatmap showing Jaccard similarity indices DE results different normalization methods comparisons. PRONE offers functionality extract consensus set DEPs based selection normalization methods threshold number methods need agree DE status protein. function get_consensus_DE() returns list consensus DE proteins either comparison separately comparisons combined.
code: intersections <- plot_upset_DE(de_res, ain = NULL,                                 comparisons = comparisons[seq_len(3)],                                 min_degree = 6, plot_type = "stacked") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. # put legend on top due to very long comparisons intersections$upset[[2]] <- intersections$upset[[2]] +    ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "top", legend.direction = "vertical") intersections$upset plot_jaccard_heatmap(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons,                       plot_type = "all") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. DT::datatable(extract_consensus_DE_candidates(de_res, ain = NULL,                                                comparisons = comparisons,                                                norm_thr = 0.8,                                                per_comparison = TRUE),                options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: Finally, biologically interpret DE results different normalization methods, PRONE offers ability perform functional enrichment different sets DE proteins originating different normalization methods. function plot_intersection_enrichment() can used visualize functional enrichment results DE proteins different normalization methods. function returns two types plot: heatmap enriched terms visualizing whether term enriched DE set specific normalization method heatmap showing Jaccard similarity coefficients quantify similarity enriched terms different normalization methods. analysis, gprofiler2 package used perform functional enrichment analysis. following parameters required: se: SummarizedExperiment object de_res: DE results comparison: Specific comparison ain: Vector normalization methods perform functional enrichment id_column: Column name rowData SummarizedExperiment object includes gene names. MaxQuant data provided multiple gene names per protein group, entries id_column split “;”. organism: Organism name (gprofiler parameter, example: hsapiens, mmusculus) source: Data source use (gprofiler parameter, example: KEGG, GO:BP, GO:MF, GO:CC, REAC, HP, …) Figure 5.1: Heatmap showing enriched terms DE sets different normalization methods specific comparison. Figure 5.2: Heatmap showing Jaccard similarity indices enriched terms different normalization methods specific comparison.
code: enrich_results <- plot_intersection_enrichment(se, de_res, comparison = "PTB-HC",                               ain = c("IRS_on_Median", "IRS_on_RobNorm", "RobNorm"),                               id_column = "Gene.Names", organism = "hsapiens",                               source = "KEGG", signif_thr = 0.05) enrich_results$enrichment_term_plot enrich_results$jaccard_intersection_plot

title: Imputation
text: seen Preprocessing phase, samples “1.HC_Pool1” “1.HC_Pool2” removed data set due high amount missing values (80% NAs per sample), imputing data remove two samples.
code: se <- remove_samples_manually(se, "Label", c("1.HC_Pool1", "1.HC_Pool2")) #> 2 samples removed.

title: Imputation
text: Since proteomics data often affected missing values statistical tests allow high amount missingness data, people options reduce amount missingness data: (1) remove proteins missing values (2) impute missing values. (1): point already shown Preprocessing tutorial, removed samples high amount missing values using predefined threshold. (2): point discussed .

title: Imputation
text: Since initial focus PRONE evaluation performance normalization methods selection methods made based extensive literature review, imputation methods currently still limited. However, ensure PRONE offers steps typical proteomics analysis workflow, included basic imputation method since cases imputation favored removing high amount proteins. currently, mixed imputation method available PRONE: k-nearest neighbor imputation proteins missing values random left-shifted Gaussian distribution proteins missing values random. Imputation can performed selection normalized data sets using “ain” parameter impute_SE function. default impute assays (ain = NULL). ATTENTION: Please note imputation can introduce bias data used caution. imputing data, look exploratory data analysis plots (boxplots, PCA plots, etc.) see imputation method skewed distributions samples introduced biases data. visualizations options already shown “Normalization” tutorial.

title: Normalization
text: , directly working SummarizedExperiment data. information create SummarizedExperiment proteomics data set, please refer “Get Started” vignette. example TMT data set originates (Biadglegne et al. 2022). SummarizedExperiment object already includes data different normalization methods. Since vignette show use PRONE workflow novel proteomics data, remove normalized data keep raw log2 data available loading data accordingly.
code: data("tuberculosis_TMT_se") se <- tuberculosis_TMT_se se <- subset_SE_by_norm(se, ain = c("raw", "log2"))

title: Normalization
text: normalization, multiple functions available can used normalize data. First , know normalization methods can applied: can use normalize_se() specifying normalization methods want apply data. instance, want perform RobNorm, median, mean normalization, just execute line: Tandem mass tag (TMT), chemical labeling method enables simultaneous MS-analysis 18 samples pooled together, increasingly applied large-scale proteomic studies. Since integration multiple TMT batches within single analysis leads high batch variation affects data quality, batch effect correction method, internal reference scaling (IRS) limma::removeBatchEffects method (PRONE: limBE), required adjust systematic biases. Commonly, batch effect correction applied basic normalization. However, order normalization batch effect correction can changed PRONE. instance, want perform IRS reduce batch effects top previously normalized data, can use combination pattern “”. Finally, can also normalize data applying specific normalization method. makes possible design parameters individual function specifically. instance, want normalize data median, can use function medianNorm(). default, median normalization performed raw-data. Using individual normalization functions, can easily specify normalized intensities stored SummarizedExperiment object can check already performed normalization techniques using: suggest using default value on_raw parameter. parameter specifies whether data normalized raw log2-transformed data. default value “on_raw” parameters made normalization method individually based publications.
code: get_normalization_methods() #>  [1] "GlobalMean"    "GlobalMedian"  "Median"        "Mean"          #>  [5] "IRS"           "Quantile"      "VSN"           "LoessF"        #>  [9] "LoessCyc"      "RLR"           "RlrMA"         "RlrMACyc"      #> [13] "EigenMS"       "MAD"           "RobNorm"       "TMM"           #> [17] "limBE"         "NormicsVSN"    "NormicsMedian" se_norm <- normalize_se(se, c("RobNorm", "Mean", "Median"),                          combination_pattern = NULL) #> RobNorm completed. #> Mean completed. #> Median completed. se_norm <- normalize_se(se, c("RobNorm", "Mean", "Median", "IRS_on_RobNorm",                          "IRS_on_Mean", "IRS_on_Median"),                          combination_pattern = "_on_") #> RobNorm completed. #> Mean completed. #> Median completed. #> IRS normalization performed on RobNorm-normalized data completed. #> IRS normalization performed on Mean-normalized data completed. #> IRS normalization performed on Median-normalized data completed. se_norm <- medianNorm(se_norm, ain = "log2", aout = "Median") names(assays(se_norm)) #> [1] "raw"            "log2"           "RobNorm"        "Mean"           #> [5] "Median"         "IRS_on_RobNorm" "IRS_on_Mean"    "IRS_on_Median"

title: Normalization
text: Sample distributions often skewed due systematic biases introduced throughout steps MS-experiment. evaluate performance normalization methods, distribution normalized data can visualized using boxplots. One expect align sample distributions closely normalization. Moreover, since normalization tries remove technical bias keeping biological variation, PCA plots log2-transformed data used analyze technical bias prominent biological variation. normalization, samples cluster according biological groups rather technical biases. may helpful analyze PCA plots different normalization techniques see normalization method mostly reduced technical bias. Finally, assessment normalization methods commonly centered ability decrease intragroup variation samples, using intragroup pooled coefficient variation (PCV), pooled estimate variance (PEV), pooled median absolute deviation (PMAD) measures variability. Furthermore, Pearson correlation samples used measure similarity samples within group. normalization method reduce intragroup variation samples increases correlation samples within group. However, please focus solely intragroup variation, also consider evaluation methods perform differential expression analysis evaluate methods analyze impact normalization downstream results. details evaluate performance normalization techniques coming along paper. published, referenced . Hence, PRONE offers many functions comparatively evaluate performance normalization methods. Notably, parameter “ain” can always set. specifying “ain = NULL”, normalization methods previously performed saved SummarizedExperiment object considered. want evaluate selection normalization methods, can specify “ain” parameter. instance, want evaluate IRS_on_RobNorm Mean normalization methods, can set “ain = c(”IRS_on_RobNorm”, “Mean”)“.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: High-throughput omics data often affected systematic biases introduced throughout steps clinical study, sample collection quantification. Failure account biases can lead erroneous results misleading conclusions downstream analysis. Normalization methods aim adjust biases make actual biological signal prominent. However, selecting appropriate normalization method challenging due wide range available approaches. Therefore, comparative evaluation unnormalized normalized data essential identifying appropriate normalization strategy specific data set. R package provides different functions preprocessing, normalizing, evaluating different normalization approaches. Furthermore, normalization methods can evaluated downstream steps, differential expression analysis statistical enrichment analysis. Spike-data sets known ground truth real-world data sets biological experiments acquired either tandem mass tag (TMT) label-free quantification (LFQ) can analyzed.

title: Getting started with PRONE
code: # Official BioC installation instructions if (!require("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager")  BiocManager::install("PRONE") # Load and attach PRONE library(PRONE)

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: six-step workflow developed R version 4.2.2 evaluate effectiveness previously defined normalization methods proteomics data. workflow incorporates set novel functions also integrates various methods adopted state---art tools. Figure 3.1: Six-step workflow PRONE. Following upload proteomics data SummarizedExperiment object, proteins many missing values can removed, outlier samples identified, normalization carried . Furthermore, exploratory analysis performance normalization methods can conducted. Finally, differential expression analysis can executed evaluate effectiveness normalization methods. data sets known ground truth, spike-simulated data sets, performance metrics, true positives (TPs), false positives (FPs), area curve (AUC) values, can computed. evaluation DE results real-world experiments based visual quality inspection, instance, using volcano plots, intersection analysis DE proteins different normalization methods available.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: guide serves introduction PRONE R package, designed facilitate preparation data set utilization PRONE package’s functionalities. begins delineating underlying data structure essential application package, followed brief description apply different normalization techniques data. Additionally, tutorial shows export normalized data end. Beyond scope introductory tutorial, PRONE encompassess broad spectrum functionalities, ranging preprocessing steps, imputation, normalization evaluation performance different normalization techniques, identification differentially expressed proteins. functionalities detailed dedicated vignettes, offering detailed insights instructions leveraging full capabilities PRONE package: Preprocessing Tutorial Imputation Tutorial Normalization Tutorial Differential Expression Tutorial Furthermore, PRONE provides additional functionalities analysis spike-data sets, detailed following vignette: Spike-Tutorial

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: PRONE uses SummarizedExperiment class storage protein intensities meta data information proteomics data set. Hence, able execute functionalities PRONE, data needs saved accordingly. , load_data() function implemented requires different parameters explained following: data: refers data.frame containing protein intensities md: refers data.frame containing meta-data information protein_column: refers column data frame contains protein IDs gene_column (optional): refers column data frame contains gene IDs condition_column (optional): refers column meta-data table contains condition information - can also specified later label_column (optional): refers column meta-data table contains sample label information - sometimes sample names long column gives option label samples shorter names visualization purposes tandem mass tag (TMT) data set samples measured different batches specify batch information. reference samples included batch, additionally specify samples names reference samples. batch_column (optional): refers column meta-data table contains batch information ref_samples (optional): refers samples used reference samples normalization Attention: need make sure sample names saved column named “Column” meta-data table named accordingly protein intensity table.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: example TMT data set originates (Biadglegne et al. 2022).
code: data_path <- readPRONE_example("tuberculosis_protein_intensities.csv") md_path <- readPRONE_example("tuberculosis_metadata.csv")  data <- read.csv(data_path) md <- read.csv(md_path)  md$Column <- stringr::str_replace_all(md$Column, " ", ".")  ref_samples <- md[md$Group == "ref",]$Column  se <- load_data(data, md, protein_column = "Protein.IDs",                  gene_column = "Gene.names", ref_samples = ref_samples,                  batch_column = "Pool", condition_column = "Group",                  label_column = "Label")

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: example data set originates (Vehmas et al. 2016). data set used subsequent examples tutorial.
code: data_path <- readPRONE_example("mouse_liver_cytochrome_P450_protein_intensities.csv") md_path <- readPRONE_example("mouse_liver_cytochrome_P450_metadata.csv")  data <- read.csv(data_path, check.names = FALSE) md <- read.csv(md_path)  se <- load_data(data, md, protein_column = "Accession",                  gene_column = "Gene names", ref_samples = NULL,                  batch_column = NULL, condition_column = "Condition",                  label_column = NULL)

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: SummarizedExperiment object contains protein intensities “assay”, meta-data table “colData”, additional columns instance resulting MaxQuant “rowData”. Furthermore, information different columns, instance, columns contains batch information, can found “metadata” slot. different data types can accessed using assays() function. Currently, raw data log2-transformed data stored SummarizedExperiment object.
code: se #> class: SummarizedExperiment  #> dim: 1499 12  #> metadata(4): condition batch refs label #> assays(2): raw log2 #> rownames(1499): 1 2 ... 1498 1499 #> rowData names(4): Gene.Names Protein.IDs Peptides used for quantitation #>   IDs #> colnames(12): 2206_WT 2208_WT ... 2285_Arom 2253_Arom #> colData names(3): Column Animal Condition assays(se) #> List of length 2 #> names(2): raw log2

what: Preprocessing, Imputation, Normalization, Evaluation, and Differential Expression
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: already mentioned introduction section, many functionalities available PRONE. functionalities mainly based SummarizedExperiment object. tutorial, perform simple normalization data using median LoessF normalization. normalized intensities saved additional assays SummarizedExperiment object. , information individual processes can find dedicated vignettes.
code: se <- normalize_se(se, c("Median", "LoessF")) #> Median completed. #> LoessF completed. assays(se) #> List of length 4 #> names(4): raw log2 Median LoessF

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Finally, can easily download normalized data using export_data() function. function save specified assays CSV files SummarizedExperiment object RDS file specified output directory. Make sure output directory exists.
code: if(!dir.exists("output/")) dir.create("output/")  export_data(se, out_dir = "output/", ain = c("log2", "Median", "LoessF"))

title: Preprocessing
code: # Load and attach PRONE library(PRONE)

title: Preprocessing
text: , directly working SummarizedExperiment data. information create SummarizedExperiment proteomics data set, please refer “Get Started” vignette. example TMT data set originates (Biadglegne et al. 2022). SummarizedExperiment object already includes data different normalization methods. Since vignette show use PRONE workflow novel proteomics data, remove normalized data keep raw log2 data available loading data accordingly.
code: data("tuberculosis_TMT_se") se <- tuberculosis_TMT_se se <- subset_SE_by_norm(se, ain = c("raw", "log2"))

title: Preprocessing
text: get overview number NAs, can simply use function get_NA_overview(): get overview number samples per sample group batch, can simply use function plot_condition_overview() specifying column meta-data used coloring. default (condition = NULL), column specified load_data() used. Figure 3.1: Overview barplot number samples per condition. Figure 3.2: Overview barplot number samples per pool. general overview protein intensities across different samples provided function plot_heatmap(). parameter “ain” specifies data plot, currently “raw” “log2” available (names(assays(se)). Later multiple normalization methods executed, saved assays, normalized data can visualized. Figure 3.3: Heatmap log2-protein intensities columns proteins clustered hclust. Similarly, upset plot can generated visualize overlaps sets defined specific column metadata. sets generated using non-NA values. Figure 3.4: Upset plot non-NA protein intensities sets defined Pool column. interested intensities specific biomarkers, can use plot_markers_boxplots() function compare distribution intensities per group. plot can generated per marker facet normalization method (facet_norm = TRUE) normalization method facet marker (facet_marker = TRUE). Figure 3.5: Boxplot log2-protein intensities markers Q92954;J3KP74;E9PLR3, Q9Y6Z7, Q68CQ4. specific biomarkers known upregulated conditions, can use plot get impression intensities differential expression analysis.
code: knitr::kable(get_NA_overview(se, ain = "log2")) plot_condition_overview(se, condition = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_condition_overview(se, condition = "Pool") available_ains <- names(assays(se))  plot_heatmap(se, ain = "log2", color_by = c("Pool", "Group"),               label_by = NULL, only_refs = FALSE) #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! #> $log2 plot_upset(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL, mb.ratio = c(0.7,0.3),             only_refs = FALSE) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! p <- plot_markers_boxplots(se,                             markers = c("Q92954;J3KP74;E9PLR3", "Q9Y6Z7"),                             ain = "log2",                             id_column = "Protein.IDs",                             facet_norm = FALSE,                             facet_marker = TRUE) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> No shaping done. p[[1]] + ggplot2::theme(axis.text.x = ggplot2::element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 0.5))

what: Remove Proteins With Missing Values in ALL Samples
title: Preprocessing
code: se <- filter_out_complete_NA_proteins(se) #> 13 proteins were removed.

what: Remove Proteins With a Specific Value in a Specific Column
title: Preprocessing
text: Typically proteins “+” columns “Reverse”, “.identified..site”, “Potential.contaminant” removed case MaxQuant proteinGroups.txt output file.
code: se <- filter_out_proteins_by_value(se, "Reverse", "+") #> 17 proteins were removed. se <- filter_out_proteins_by_value(se, "Only.identified.by.site", "+") #> 1 proteins were removed. #se <- filter_out_proteins_by_value(se, "Potential.contaminant", "+")

title: Preprocessing
text: don’t want remove instance proteins “Potential.contaminant == +”, can also first get protein ID specific value, check Uniprot, remove using function filter_out_proteins_by_ID().
code: pot_contaminants <- get_proteins_by_value(se, "Potential.contaminant", "+") #> 24 proteins were identified. se <- filter_out_proteins_by_ID(se, pot_contaminants) #> 24 proteins were removed.

title: Preprocessing
text: Due high amount missing values MS-based proteomics data, important explore missing value pattern data. function plot_NA_heatmap() provides heatmap proteins least one missing value across samples. Figure 4.1: Heatmap missing value pattern. Proteins least one missing value included heatmap. Another way explore missing value pattern use functions plot_NA_density() plot_NA_frequency(). Figure 4.2: Density plot protein intensities proteins missing values proteins without missing values. can help check whether missing values biased lower intense proteins. case, missing values biased towards lower intense proteins. Figure 4.3: Protein identification overlap. plot shows number identified proteins (y-axis) per number samples (x-axis).
code: plot_NA_heatmap(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL, cluster_samples = TRUE,                  cluster_proteins = TRUE) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_NA_density(se) plot_NA_frequency(se)

what: Filter Proteins By Applying a Missing Value Threshold
title: Preprocessing
text: reduce amount missing values, possible filter proteins applying missing value threshold. function filter_out_NA_proteins_by_threshold() removes proteins missing values specified threshold. threshold value 0 1, 0.7, instance, means proteins less 70% real values removed, .e., proteins 30% missing values removed. Figure 4.4: Heatmap missing value pattern filtering proteins many missing values (threshold set 70%). Proteins least one missing value included heatmap.
code: se <- filter_out_NA_proteins_by_threshold(se, thr = 0.7)  #> 99 proteins were removed.  plot_NA_heatmap(se) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used!

title: Preprocessing
text: Following filtering proteins different criteria, samples can analyzed detail. PRONE provides functions, plot_nr_prot_samples() plot_tot_int_samples(), get overview number proteins total intensity per sample, also offers automatic outlier detection method POMA.

title: Preprocessing
text: Figure 5.1: Barplot number non-zero proteins per samples colored condition. plot helps quality control check whether number proteins similar across samples. case, proteins detected sample 1.HC_Pool1 compared samples. Figure 5.2: Barplot total protein intensity per samples colored condition. plot helps quality control check whether total protein intensity similar across samples. case, total protein intensities samples 1.HC_Pool1 1.HC_Pool2 much lower compared samples.
code: plot_nr_prot_samples(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_tot_int_samples(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used!

title: Preprocessing
text: Based plots, samples “1.HC_Pool1” 1_HC_Pool2 seem outliers. can easily remove samples manually using remove_samples_manually() function.
code: se <- remove_samples_manually(se, "Label", c("1.HC_Pool1", "1.HC_Pool2")) #> 2 samples removed.

title: Preprocessing
text: can remove reference samples directly using function remove_reference_samples(). attention: possibly need normalization! exactly currently keep !
code: se_no_refs <- remove_reference_samples(se) #> 2 reference samples removed from the SummarizedExperiment object.

what: Outlier Detection via POMA R Package
title: Preprocessing
text: POMA R package provides method detect outliers proteomics data. function detect_outliers_POMA() detects outliers data based POMA algorithm. method calculates euclidean distances (maximum manhattan distances) sample pairs group centroids computed either average distance group members spatial median. distances group members corresponding group centroid calculated apply classical univariate outlier detection formula Q3 + 1.5 * IQR (1.5 adjustable) detect group-dependent outliers. function returns list following elements: polygon plot, distance boxplot, outliers. information POMA algorithm, please refer original publication (Castellano-Escuder et al. 2021): Figure 5.3: Polygon plot principal coordinates calculated using POMA algorithm. original distances reduced principal coordinates (see POMA vegan::betadisper method). Figure 5.4: Boxplot distances samples group centroid calculated using POMA. Table 5.1: Outliers detected POMA algorithm. remove outliers detected via POMA algorithm, just put data.table detect_outliers_POMA() function remove_POMA_outliers() function.
code: poma_res <- detect_outliers_POMA(se, ain = "log2") #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Scale for fill is already present. #> Adding another scale for fill, which will replace the existing scale. #> Scale for colour is already present. #> Adding another scale for colour, which will replace the existing scale. #> Scale for fill is already present. #> Adding another scale for fill, which will replace the existing scale. poma_res$polygon_plot poma_res$distance_boxplot knitr::kable(poma_res$outliers,               caption = "Outliers detected by the POMA algorithm.", digits = 2) se <- remove_POMA_outliers(se, poma_res$outliers) #> 1 outlier samples removed.

title: PRONE with Spike-In Data
code: library(PRONE)

title: PRONE with Spike-In Data
text: PRONE also offers additional functionalities evaluation normalization techniques spike-data sets known ground truth. functionalities delineated subsequently. Additionally, functionalities detailed context real-world data sets remain applicable SummarizedExperiment object associated spike-data sets. example spike-data set (Cox et al. 2014). illustration package functionality, smaller subset data consisting 1500 proteins used. complete data set, please refer original publication.
code: data_path <- readPRONE_example("Ecoli_human_MaxLFQ_protein_intensities.csv") md_path <- readPRONE_example("Ecoli_human_MaxLFQ_metadata.csv")  data <- read.csv(data_path) md <- read.csv(md_path)

title: PRONE with Spike-In Data
text: loading data SummarizedExperiment object, important check organism protein groups. Proteins uniquely assigned either spike-organism background organism. protein groups mixed, removed data since can’t used classification true positives, false positives, etc. example, can extract information “Fasta.headers” column: case, proteins assigned either spike-background protein. Hence, SummarizedExperiment container data can created. However, need add column actual organism can used calculate true positives, false positives, etc. contrast real-world data sets, need specify “spike_column”, “spike_value”, “spike_concentration”, utilize load_spike_data() function purpose. , “spike_column” denotes column protein intensity data file encompassing information whether proteins classified spike-background protein. “spike_value” determines value/identifier used identify spike-proteins “spike_column”, “spike_concentration” identifies column containing concentration values spike-proteins (case different conditions tested DE analysis).
code: # Check if some protein groups are mixed mixed <- grepl("Homo sapiens.*Escherichia|Escherichia.*Homo sapiens",data$Fasta.headers)  data <- data[!mixed,]  table(mixed)  #> mixed #> FALSE  #>  1000 data$Spiked <- rep("HUMAN", nrow(data)) data$Spiked[grepl("ECOLI", data$Fasta.headers)] <- "ECOLI" se <- load_spike_data(data,                        md,                        spike_column = "Spiked",                        spike_value = "ECOLI",                        spike_concentration = "Concentration",                       protein_column = "Protein.IDs",                        gene_column = "Gene.names",                        ref_samples = NULL,                        batch_column = NULL,                        condition_column = "Condition",                        label_column = "Label")

title: PRONE with Spike-In Data
text: get overview number identified (non-NA) spike-proteins per sample, can use plot_identified_spiked_proteins() function. Figure 4.1: Overview number identified spike-proteins per sample, colored condition. data set, conditions labeled H L. H indicates sample group high concentrations spike-proteins added background proteome, L represents sample group low concentrations. compare distributions spike-human proteins different sample groups (high-low), use function plot_histogram_spiked(). , “condition = NULL” means condition specified loading data used, can also specify column meta data. Figure 4.2: Histogram protein intensities spike-proteins (ECOLI) background proteins (HUMAN) different conditions. plot helps compare distributions spike-(red) background proteins (grey) different spike-levels. want look amount actual measure spike-, can use plot_profiles_spiked() function. Moreover, can analyze whether intensities background proteins, HUMAN proteins, constant across different spike-concentrations. Figure 4.3: Profiles spike-proteins (ECOLI) background proteins (HUMAN) different conditions. plot helps analyze whether intensities background proteins constant across different spike-concentrations. Spike-proteins (red) increase intensity increasing spike-concentrations, background proteins (grey) remain constant.

title: PRONE with Spike-In Data
text: First, need specify comparisons want perform DE analysis. , special function developed helps build right comparison strings. can run DE analysis:
code: comparisons <- specify_comparisons(se_norm, condition = "Condition",                                     sep = NULL, control = NULL) de_res <- run_DE(se = se_norm,                       comparisons = comparisons,                      ain = NULL,                       condition = NULL,                       DE_method = "limma",                       covariate = NULL,                       logFC = TRUE,                       logFC_up = 1,                       logFC_down = -1,                       p_adj = TRUE,                       alpha = 0.05,                       B = 100,                       K = 500) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> DE Analysis will not be performed on raw data. #> log2: DE analysis completed. #> Median: DE analysis completed. #> Mean: DE analysis completed. #> MAD: DE analysis completed. #> LoessF: DE analysis completed.

what: Evaluate DE Results with Performance Metrics
title: PRONE with Spike-In Data
text: able visualize DE results, need run get_spiked_stats_DE() calculate multiple performance metrics, number true positives, number fo false positives, etc. Table 6.1: Performance metrics different normalization methods pairwise comparisons. different options visualize amount true false positives different normalization techniques pairwise comparisons. functions, can specify subset normalization methods comparisons. specify anything, normalization methods comparisons “stats” data frame used. plot_TP_FP_spiked_bar() function generates barplot showing number false positives true positives normalization method facetted pairwise comparison. Figure 6.1: Barplot showing number false positives (FP) true positives (TP) normalization method facetted pairwise comparison. plot shows impact normalization DE results. many pairwise comparisons performed, plot_TP_FP_spiked_box() function can used visualize distribution true false positives pairwise comparisons boxplot. Given data set encompasses merely two distinct spike-concentrations therefore one pairwise comparison conducted DE analysis, barplot appropriate. Nonetheless, demonstration purposes, boxplot used . Figure 6.2: Boxplot showing distribution true positives (TP) false positives (FP) normalization method across pairwise comparisons. plot helps visualize distribution TP FP normalization method. Since dataset, two conditions available, hence single pairwise comparison, plot informative. Furthermore, similarly plot_TP_FP_spiked_scatter() function can used visualize true false positives scatter plot. , scatterplot median true positives false positives calculated across comparisons displayed normalization method errorbars showing Q1 Q3. , plot suitable data sets multiple pairwise comparisons. Figure 6.3: Scatter plot showing median true positives (TP) false positives (FP) normalization method across pairwise comparisons. Furthermore, performance metrics number true positives false positives can visualized using plot_stats_spiked_heatmap() function. , currently, sensitivity, specificity, precision, FPR, F1 score, accuracy can visualized different normalization methods pairwise comparisons. Figure 6.4: Heatmap showing selection performance metrics different normalization methods pairwise comparisons. Finally, receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves AUC values can calculated visualized using plot_ROC_AUC_spiked() function. function returns plot showing ROC curves, bar plot AUC values comparison, boxplot distributions AUC values across comparisons. Figure 6.5: ROC curves AUC barplots boxplots different normalization methods pairwise comparisons. AUC barplots shown pairwise comparison, boxplot shows distribution AUC values across comparisons. Figure 6.6: ROC curves AUC barplots boxplots different normalization methods pairwise comparisons. AUC barplots shown pairwise comparison, boxplot shows distribution AUC values across comparisons. Figure 6.7: ROC curves AUC barplots boxplots different normalization methods pairwise comparisons. AUC barplots shown pairwise comparison, boxplot shows distribution AUC values across comparisons.
code: stats <- get_spiked_stats_DE(se_norm, de_res)  # Show tp, fp, fn, tn, with F1 score knitr::kable(stats[,c("Assay", "Comparison", "TP", "FP", "FN", "TN", "F1Score")], caption = "Performance metrics for the different normalization methods and pairwise comparisons.", digits = 2) plot_TP_FP_spiked_bar(stats, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD", "LoessF"),                        comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. plot_TP_FP_spiked_box(stats, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD", "LoessF"),                        comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. plot_TP_FP_spiked_scatter(stats, ain = NULL, comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. plot_stats_spiked_heatmap(stats, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD"),                            metrics = c("Precision", "F1Score")) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. plot_ROC_AUC_spiked(se_norm, de_res, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "LoessF"),                      comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of de_res will be visualized. #> $ROC #>  #> $AUC_bars #>  #> $AUC_box #>  #> $AUC_dt #>   PANEL Comparison group  Assay       AUC #> 1     1        H-L     1 LoessF 0.8654546 #> 2     1        H-L     2   Mean 0.7693012 #> 3     1        H-L     3 Median 0.8638456

title: The PROteomics Normalization Evaluator
text: High-throughput omics data often affected systematic biases introduced throughout steps clinical study, sample collection quantification. Failure account biases can lead erroneous results misleading conclusions downstream analysis. Normalization methods aim adjust biases make actual biological signal prominent. However, selecting appropriate normalization method challenging due wide range available approaches. Therefore, comparative evaluation unnormalized normalized data essential identifying appropriate normalization strategy specific data set. R package provides different functions preprocessing, normalizing, evaluating different normalization approaches. Furthermore, normalization methods can evaluated downstream steps, differential expression analysis statistical enrichment analysis. Spike-data sets known ground truth real-world data sets biological experiments acquired either tandem mass tag (TMT) label-free quantification (LFQ) can analyzed.

title: The PROteomics Normalization Evaluator
text: install package, run: troubles downloading PRONE Bioconductor, still option install PRONE GitHub. However, Bioconductor download recommended!
code: # Official BioC installation instructions   if (!require("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager")    BiocManager::install("PRONE")      # Load and attach PRONE    library("PRONE") # Install PRONE.R from github and build vignettes   if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)){     install.packages("devtools")   }    devtools::install_github("daisybio/PRONE", build_vignettes = TRUE,                             dependencies = TRUE)      # Load and attach PRONE    library("PRONE")

what: Method to impute SummarizedExperiment. This method performs a mixed imputation on the proteins. It uses a k-nearest neighbor imputation for proteins with missing values at random (MAR) and imputes missing values by random draws from a left-shifted Gaussian distribution for proteins with missing values not at random (MNAR). — impute_se

It uses a k-nearest neighbor imputation for proteins with missing values at random (MAR) and imputes missing values by random draws from a left-shifted Gaussian distribution for proteins with missing values not at random (MNAR). — impute_se
code: data(tuberculosis_TMT_se) tuberculosis_TMT_se <- remove_samples_manually(tuberculosis_TMT_se,                           column = "Label", values = c("1.HC_Pool1")) #> 1 samples removed. tuberculosis_TMT_se <- impute_se(tuberculosis_TMT_se, ain = NULL,                           condition = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows). #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows). #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows). #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows). #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows). #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows).

title: Load real-world proteomics data into a SummarizedExperiment — load_data
code: data_path <- readPRONE_example("tuberculosis_protein_intensities.csv") md_path <- readPRONE_example("tuberculosis_metadata.csv") data <- read.csv(data_path) md <- read.csv(md_path) md$Column <- stringr::str_replace_all(md$Column, " ", ".") ref_samples <- md[md$Group == "ref",]$Column se <- load_data(data, md, protein_column = "Protein.IDs",                gene_column = "Gene.names", ref_samples = ref_samples,                batch_column = "Pool", condition_column = "Group",                label_column = "Label")

code: data_path <- readPRONE_example("Ecoli_human_MaxLFQ_protein_intensities.csv") md_path <- readPRONE_example("Ecoli_human_MaxLFQ_metadata.csv") data <- read.csv(data_path) md <- read.csv(md_path) mixed <- grepl("Homo sapiens.*Escherichia|Escherichia.*Homo sapiens", data$Fasta.headers) data <- data[!mixed,] data$Spiked <- rep("HUMAN", nrow(data)) data$Spiked[grepl("ECOLI", data$Fasta.headers)] <- "ECOLI" se <- load_spike_data(data, md, spike_column = "Spiked", spike_value = "ECOLI",          spike_concentration = "Concentration", protein_column = "Protein.IDs",          gene_column = "Gene.names", ref_samples = NULL, batch_column = NULL,          condition_column = "Condition", label_column = "Label")

title: Normalize SummarizedExperiment object using single normalization methods or specified combinations of normalization methods — normalize_se
text: se SummarizedExperiment containing necessary information proteomics data set methods Vector normalization methods apply normalizing proteomics data SummarizedExperiment object (identifier normalization methods can retrieved using get_normalization_methods()) combination_pattern String specifying normalization methods combined. instance, methods = c("IRS", "Median_on_IRS"), combination_pattern = "_on_". on_raw Logical indicating normalization performed raw data log2-transformed data. on_raw = NULL(default), normalization performed default method specific on_raw setting (suggestion based publications). gamma.0 Numeric representing exponent weighted density RobNorm normalization. sample size small, fitted population proteins locally trapped variance proteins small large gamma. avoid , small gamma recommended. sample size smaller 40, set gamma 0.5 0.1. reduce_correlation_by data big computation params, increase parameter 2,3,4.... whole data still normalized, params calculated every second row etc. NormicsVSN_quantile quantile used resistant least trimmed sum squares regression. value 0.8 means focusing central 80% data, reducing influence outliers. top_x Number reference proteins extracted calculation parameters VSN_quantile Numeric length 1. quantile used resistant least trimmed sum squares regression (see vsn2 lts.quantile)

what: Quantile Normalization of preprocessCore package. — quantileNorm
title: Quantile Normalization of preprocessCore package. — quantileNorm
text: Forces distributions samples basis quantiles samples replacing protein sample mean corresponding quantile. Log2-scaled data taken input (on_raw = FALSE)

code: quantileNorm(se, ain = "log2", aout = "Quantile", on_raw = FALSE)

title: Quantile Normalization of preprocessCore package. — quantileNorm
text: se SummarizedExperiment containing necessary information proteomic dataset ain String assay used input aout String assay used save normalized data on_raw Boolean specifying whether normalization performed raw log2-scaled data

title: Quantile Normalization of preprocessCore package. — quantileNorm
text: SummarizedExperiment containing quantile normalized data assay (log2 scale)

title: Quantile Normalization of preprocessCore package. — quantileNorm
code: data(tuberculosis_TMT_se) tuberculosis_TMT_se <- quantileNorm(tuberculosis_TMT_se, ain = "log2",                               aout = "Quantile", on_raw = FALSE)

Hence, no samples were removed.
